title: 114_hr4783
content: The Act titled "Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016" extends termination dates for SBIR and STTR programs from 2017 to 2022. Administrative funding deadlines are also extended to 2022. Required expenditure amounts are specified in Section 3. The Small Business Act is amended to increase budget percentages for SBIR and STTR programs from fiscal year 2018 to 2022 and beyond. The Small Business Act is amended to increase budget percentages for SBIR and STTR programs from fiscal year 2018 onwards, with increments each year until reaching 0.60 percent in fiscal year 2022 and beyond. SEC. 4. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. Amendments to the Small Business Act require reports to be submitted annually by December 31 and not later than March 30 of each year to the Small Business Administration. The reports must be simplified, standardized, and timely. Amendments to the Small Business Act now require each agency to submit a report to the Administration by March 30 of each year on specific instances. Amendments to the Small Business Act now require agencies to submit reports to the Administrator by specific deadlines each year, including June 30 and March 30. Failure to report administrative funds by March 30 may result in consequences. If a Federal agency fails to submit a required report, paragraph (1) won't apply unless the report is submitted, and a plan for timely reporting is provided to the Administrator. SEC. 5. INDEXING AWARDS FOR INFLATION. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to adjust awards for inflation in Phase I and Phase II of SBIR or STTR programs. Phase I awards are capped at $150,000, and Phase II awards are also adjusted. Phase II awards for SBIR or STTR programs are capped at $1,000,000 and will be adjusted for inflation according to section 1908 of title 41, United States Code. SEC. 6 amends the Small Business Act to change the wording regarding insertion incentives. SEC. 7 clarifies the eligibility of certain small businesses. The Small Business Act is amended to clarify the eligibility of certain small businesses for the SBIR and STTR programs. The Administrator is required to modify policy directives to ensure that specific small business concerns are eligible to receive awards under the programs. Small business concerns in certain categories are eligible for awards under the STTR program. SEC. 8. COMMERCIALIZATION ASSISTANCE PILOT PROGRAM. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to include a Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program, requiring covered agencies to implement a program to award eligible entities with a second sequential SBIR award. The program should not exceed 5 percent of the agency's total SBIR funds. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program limits the use of SBIR budget to 5 percent and will end on September 30, 2022. Matching funds from a third-party investor are required for awards, and ineligible sources cannot be used. Awards under the program have specific size criteria. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program sets limitations on award size and timing, with awards distributed during Phase II. To qualify for a second SBIR award, eligible entities must submit an application with required information and matching funding details. Funds awarded can only be used for research and development activities. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program awards funds during Phase II to aid in commercializing research. Recipients are determined based on the potential impact on commercialization, technical feasibility, improvements to the commercialization plan, and progress in Phase II activities. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program evaluates the impact of third-party funding on commercial and societal benefits. The Comptroller General will submit an evaluative report on the program's activities and results achieved by small businesses. The evaluation report on the Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program will include data on commercialization rates, employment and revenue growth, comparison with non-matching Phase II recipients, demographic information, fund usage, third-party funding sources, program effectiveness analysis, and recommendations for improvement if the program becomes permanent. The term 'covered agency' refers to a Federal agency with an SBIR program. An 'eligible entity' is a small business that has received Phase II awards from the covered agency. An 'eligible third-party investor' can be a small business, venture capital firm, individual investor, or government entity. 'Ineligible sources' include the awardee's internal funds and non-cash funding. The eligible entity can receive funding from owners, family members, affiliates, or through loans. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to increase underserved population participation by using funds for outreach and technical assistance. Additionally, a conforming amendment removes the waiver authority for certain uses.
